infoSource: Boeing, www.boeing.com/history/products/b-29-superfortress.page.
name: B-29 Superfortress
description: The B-29 was one of the most technologically advanced planes of World War II. It had remotely controlled machine guns, a pressurized cabin, and other brand new features for World War II. It also carried the Atomic Bomb which ultimately ended the war.
The B-24 was a heavy bomber introduced in 1942. It could carry 8,000 pounds of bombs over 2,800 miles.
name: B-24 Liberator
infoSource: “Consolidated B-24 Liberator: The National WWII Museum: New Orleans.” The National WWII Museum | New Orleans, www.nationalww2museum.org/visit/museum-campus/us-freedom-pavilion/warbirds/consolidated-b-24-liberator.

name: P-26 Peashooter
infoSource: Boeing, www.boeing.com/history/products/p-26-peashooter.page.
description: The Boeing P-26 was a fighter plane used in World War Two. Its first flight was March 20,1932. It has a wingspan of 28 feet and a max speed of 234 mph, with the power to hold 200 pounds of bombs.

The Spitfire was one of Britain's most influential aircraft, with a max speed of 408 mph and a ceiling of 44,000 feet. The engines were known for starting quickly and many Royal Air Force pilots loved the simplicity of the cockpit.
infoSource: Ethell, Jeff. “Supermarine Spitfire.” Air & Space Magazine, www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/supermarine-spitfire-134209906/.
name: Supermarine Spitfire

infoSource: “Bell P-39 Airacobra.” Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 15 May 2021, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_P-39_Airacobra.
description: The P-39 was built for high altitude combat. It was used in many countries, including Australia, the UK, the US, France. After the war, it was used for racing.
name: P-39 Airacobra
Supermarine Seafire
infoSource: “Supermarine Seafire.” Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 13 Apr. 2021, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermarine_Seafire.
description: The Seafire was the naval version of the Supermarine Spitfire, adapted for operation from aircraft carriers. It had all the advantages of a Spitfire, but was able to be launched from an aircraft carrier. It was also an able interceptor of Japan's Kamikaze attacks.

name: P-40 Warhawk
description: The P-40 was used mostly for frontline service. Although it was the third most-produced American fighter of World War II it lacked in speed against the Axis powers' supercharged planes.
infoSource: “Curtiss P-40 Warhawk.” Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 15 May 2021, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtiss_P-40_Warhawk.

description: The B-17 is a not as well known aircraft that contributed much to the cause of World War ll. It was the third most produced bomber in America, it was well-known for its toughness and endurance, and it dropped more bombs than any other bomber in World War ll.
name: B-17
infoSource: “Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress.” Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 13 May 2021, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_B-17_Flying_Fortress.

name: Bristol Beaufort
description: The Bristol Beaufort served as a torpedo bomber and a mine-layer starting in 1940 until is was retired as a trainer in 1942.
infoSource: “Bristol Beaufort.” Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 14 Apr. 2021, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bristol_Beaufort.
“A-26/B-26 Invader Light Bomber.” Boeing, Boeing, www.boeing.com/history/products/a26-b26-invader-light-bomber.page.
name: Douglas A-26 Invader
description: The Douglas A-26 bomber was the only American bomber to fly missions in three wars: World War ll, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War. The A-26 was used for reconnaissance, light bombing, and training.

infoSource: Budanovic, Nikola. “XB-19: The Bomber That Never Got to Fight But Did Have Its Own Kitchen.” WAR HISTORY ONLINE, 13 July 2019, www.warhistoryonline.com/instant-articles/xb-19-the-bomber-that-never-got-to-fight-but-did-have-its-own-kitchen.html.
name: Douglas XB-19
description: The XB-19 was a long range bomber that was only flown a handful of times. As an experimental aircraft, it never got to see active duty. It dwarfed its predecessors but was deemed obsolete.

infoSource: “Curtiss SB2C Helldiver: The ‘Big-Tailed Beast.’” National Air and Space Museum, airandspace.si.edu/stories/editorial/curtiss-sb2c-helldiver-big-tailed-beast.
name: Curtiss SB2C
description: The Curtiss SB2C was going to be one of the top competitors in the naval air force world, but because its development was delayed, by the time it got out, there were other planes that were equal to or better than the SB2C.

infoSource: “North American A-36.” The American Heritage Museum, 10 July 2020, www.americanheritagemuseum.org/aircrafts/north-american-36-apache/.
name: A-36
description: The A-36 was a derivative of the P-51 mustang used for dive bombing. It had a maximum speed of 365 MPH, making it superior to its competitors.

name: P-51 Mustang
infoSource: “P-51.” Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., www.britannica.com/technology/P-51.
description: The P-51 is widely regarded as the finest all-around fighter of World War II. It had a top speed of 390 MPH and a range of 1,375 miles.

name: P-36 Hawk
infoSource: The Curtiss P-36 Hawk, www.aviation-history.com/curtiss/p36.htm.
description: The P-26 Hawk was one of the first monoplanes used in the air force. It introduced a new era of fighter planes and led the way towards the modern age.

The Hawker Hurricane was a British monoplane that played a major role in WWll. It contributed to 60% of the air victories in the Battle of Britain. Overall, there were about 14,483 Hawker Hurricanes produced during WWll.
infoSource: “Hawker Hurricane.” BAE Systems | International, www.baesystems.com/en/heritage/hurricane.
name: Hawker Hurricane
Messerschmitt Bf 109
infoSource: Messerschmitt Bf 109, www.aviation-history.com/messerschmitt/bf109.html.
description: The Bf 109 was Germany's top fighter plane. It was supepior to any other plane at that time and dominated the air during WWll.

The P-38  was originally designed as a bomber-interceptor and was never intended to be a fighter. It shot down more Japanese planes than any other American fighter. It was a fine competitor to the Supermarine Spitfire and the Messerschmitt Bf 109.
name: P-38 Lightning
infoSource: Lockheed P-38 Lightning, The Aviation History Online Museum, www.aviation-history.com/lockheed/p38.html.

description: The P-80 was the first American jet fighter. It could hit speeds close to 580 MPH. It played a big role at the end of World War ll as it far surpassed the rest of the competition.
name: P-80 Shooting Star
infoSource: Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star, The Aviation History Online Museum, www.aviation-history.com/lockheed/p80.html.

Budanovic, Nikola. “The B-32 Dominator: The Heavy Bomber in Service for Less Than a Year.” WAR HISTORY ONLINE, 10 June 2019, www.warhistoryonline.com/instant-articles/the-b-32-dominator-the-heavy-bomber-in-service-for-less-than-a-year.html.
name: B-32 Dominator
description: The B-32 was in essence the little brother to the well-known B-29. As the backup plan for the B-29, the B-32 didn't see combat until very late in the war, making it the last Allied aircraft to be engaged in combat during World War II. Having only served for 7 months, it was one of the shortest-serving aircraft in US history.

name: F4U Corsair
infoSource: “Chance Vought F4U Corsair.” National Museum of World War II Aviation, 10 May 2021, www.worldwariiaviation.org/chance-vought-f4u-corsair/.
description: The Corsair had a distinct gull-wing design, allowing the engine to mounted higher, enabling a bigger prop to be used, giving it more power. It piled up over 2,000 victories and was nicknamed the "Whistling Death" by the Japanese for its unique sound when attacking at low altitudes.

name: Douglas DC-3
description: The DC-3 was famous for its transportation abilities in World War ll. It was used for every possible task in the war, from freight and personnel transport to glider tug and ambulance use. After the war it was used world-wide by passenger airlines, becoming one of the most famous passenger airplanes.
infoSource: Douglas DC-3, The Aviation History Online Museum, www.aviation-history.com/douglas/dc3.html.

description: The O-47 was an observation aircraft that lived in an age where observation planes were very popular, but continued to become obsolete because of the rapid development in the world of fighter aircraft. Observation craft were too slow, too large, too lightly armed, and lacked maneuverability. They were sitting ducks for thenew advanced fighters.
infoSource: North American 0-47B, Combat Air Museum, www.combatairmuseum.org/aircraft/namerican047b.html.
imgsrc: Aircraft of World War II - WW2Aircraft.net Forums
name: North American O-47
Boeing 314
infoSource: “Boeing.” Boeing's Model 314 Clipper Flying Boat, History Link, www.historylink.org/File/3253.
description: The Boeing 314 was a trans-atlantic passenger airline that was used to ferry many important people across the Atlantic Ocean. It flew President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill across for many of the conferences near the end of the war, making it the first presidential airplane.

The F2A was the USA's first monoplane fighter. Even thought it was the smallest naval fighter at the time, it was extremely heavy. This led to many problems that they tried to fix with bigger engines, but ultimately it was found as vain and was soon replaced with the F4F Wildcat.
name: F2A Buffalo
infoSource: “Brewster F2A Buffalo Fighter.” Brewster F2A Buffalo Fighter - WWII American Aircraft, World War 2 Headquarters, worldwar2headquarters.com/HTML/aircraft/americanAircraft/buffalo.html.

name: F4F Wildcat
infoSource: Maksel, Rebecca. “The ‘Hit and Git’ Fighter.” Air & Space Magazine, Air & Space Magazine, 22 Aug. 2017, www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/the-hit-and-git-fighter-180964344/.
description: The F4F Wildcat was the first plane to put up a successful fight against Japan's A6M Zero. The Wildcat played a major role in the beginning of World War ll and led the way for modern naval aircraft.

infoSource: Door, Robert F. “Vultee P-66 Vanguard.” Defense Media Network, 23 Jan. 2013, www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/vultee-p-66-vanguard. Accessed 31 May 2021.
description: The P-66 was a "might have been" plane that didn't find the right role. It was produced too late in the war to contribute at all to the war effort. Although it might have been superior a few years earlier, it was outmatched in speed and maneuverability in the air at the time it was developed.
name: P-66 Vanguard

infoSource: “De Havilland Mosquito.” BAE Systems | International, BAE Systems, www.baesystems.com/en/heritage/de-havilland-mosquito.
name: Havilland Mosquito
description: The Mosquito was the UK's most successful bomber. Their plan was to make a bomber that had such outstanding performance that it wouldn't need ay defensive equipment. With a maximum speed of 408 MPH, the Mosquito was the fastest bomber in World War ll, making it extremely successful.

infoSource: Aceto, Guy. “How the B-25 Became the Ultimate Strafer of World War II.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 26 Mar. 2021, www.historynet.com/the-mighty-mitchell-how-b-25s-became-one-of-the-most-essential-aircraft-in-wwii.htm.
description: The B-25 was a type of bomber that was armed to the teeth and was especially successful in low altitude raids and strafing. It was the only plane to bomb Tokyo before the B-29s came and started taking over their job. It had the second longest-lasting career for an American bomber with only the B-17 being in front of it.
name: B-25 Mitchell

infoSource: Aceto, Guy. “How the Me-110 Became a Bomber's Worst Nightmare.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 30 Sept. 2019, www.historynet.com/how-the-me-110-became-a-bombers-worst-nightmare.htm.
description: The Bf 110 didn't do very well as a regular fighter as proved in the Battle of Britain, but it showed itself as a competitor during the night. It was heavily armed in the nose, sides, and rear. It had an enormous cockpit that could accommodate a radarman and his electronics enabling space for the equipment that allowed for advanced instrument flight.
name: Messerschmitt Bf 110

description: The Stinson L-1 Vigilant was a very versatile aircraft using during WWII for shorter flights. L-1s were converted and used for a variety of tasks like training, emergency rescue, supply transport, and even dropping light bombs.
infoSource: Clark/Nikdel/Powell. “1941 Stinson Vultee L-1E | Fantasy of Flight.” Fantasy of Flight |, 17 Sept. 2013, www.fantasyofflight.com/collection/aircraft/currently-not-showing-in-museum/golden-age/1941-stinson-vultee-l-1e/. Accessed 26 May 2021.
name: L-1, O-49 Vigilant

description: The Martin Baltimore was an attack bomber that was heavily armed and had a 61-foot wingspan. t had a 2,000-pound bombload and carried a powerful sting for aerial combat. It was easy to handle and had good maneuverability.
name: Martin Baltimore
infoSource: Chan, Amy. “The Forgotten Bomber: The Martin A-30 Baltimore.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 15 May 2017, www.historynet.com/forgotten-bomber-martin-30-baltimore.htm.

description: The B-26 was a medium bomber that played a big role in World War ll. The Air Force designed it to have the capabilities of a bomber, but the speed of a fighter.
name: B-26 Marauder
infoSource: Mbartels. “The B-26 Marauder: World War II Medium Bomber.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 25 Mar. 2019, www.historynet.com/b-26b-marauder-american-bomber-in-world-war-ii.htm.
Aceto, Guy. “Avro Lancaster: The Night Raider.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 21 May 2019, www.historynet.com/night-raider.htm.
name: Avro Lancaster
description: The Avro Lancaster had a bombload greater than any other bomber in World War ll. It was the only plane that was able to carry the massive bomb called the "Grand Slam", Britain's heaviest and most powerful bomb. The Lancaster was unique to other planes during that time as it performed wonderfully right after it came out of the factories.

The Fw 190 was a brilliant German fighter that was second only in importance to the Bf 109. It gave heavy bombers like the B-17 and B-24 nightmares and was only beaten after 2 years when the appearance of the P-38 Lightnings and the P-47 Thunderbolts with their turbocharged engines eventually became too much for the Fw 109 to handle.
infoSource: Guilmartin, John F. “Fw 190.” Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., www.britannica.com/technology/Fw-190.
name: Focke-Wulf Fw 190
Mitsubishi A6M Zero
description: The A6M Zero was easily the most dominant fighter early in World War ll. It had incredible maneuverability and was flown against the Allied forces who had never credited the Japanese with the ability to design such a successful fighter. The engineers wanted to make the plane as light as possible, so they drilled holes through the internal frame, a technique used by many racecar builders.
infoSource: Chan, Amy. “Myth of the Zero.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 29 Nov. 2017, www.historynet.com/myth-of-the-zero.htm.

name: Messerschmitt Me 262
description: The Me 262 was the first jet-propelled fighter of World War ll. It led to the new era of jet and rocket-powered airplanes. It entered the war late but still managed to perform beyond expectations.
infoSource: Chan, Amy. “Me-262: Harbinger of a New Era.” HistoryNet, HistoryNet, 26 May 2020, www.historynet.com/harbinger-new-era.htm.

description: The SBD Dauntless was one of the US's most influential dive bombers in the Pacific. It played a major part in the Battle of MIdway when it destroyed 4 aircraft carriers. Being able to be launched from an aircraft carrier, it was extremely more useful than if it was just a regular dive bomber or fighter.
infoSource: “Douglas SBD-6 Dauntless.” Douglas SBD-6 Dauntless | National Air and Space Museum, National Air and Space Museum, airandspace.si.edu/collection-objects/douglas-sbd-6-dauntless/nasm_A19610109000.
name: Douglas SBD Dauntless
